recommendations.title: Face Masks: What Doctors Say About Their Role In Containing Coronavirus
recommendations.excerpt: As the Wuhan coronavirus continues to spread, officials in China are urging citizens to wear masks in public to stop the spread of the virus — and cities in China as well as other parts of Asia are reportedly running out of face masks. But can a mask really keep you from catching the virus?

recommendations.title: The Only Texas Chili Recipe You’ll Ever Need
recommendations.excerpt: The origins of the robust dish Texans fervently claim as their own are, as food writers are wont to say, lost to history.

recommendations.title: Why Britain Brexited
recommendations.excerpt: The United Kingdom will soon begin the most radical national experiment of the 21st century so far: Brexit. Having won a landslide election victory on a promise to “get Brexit done,” Boris Johnson will finally make good on 2016’s referendum result.

recommendations.title: An update to a 37-year-old digital protocol could profoundly change the way music sounds
recommendations.excerpt: A lot of big things happened in music in 1983. It was the year Michael Jackson’s album Thriller hit number one across the world, compact discs were first released in the US, and the Red Hot Chili Peppers formed. Yet there was one obscure event that was more influential than all of them: MIDI 1.

recommendations.title: Dyslexia Doesn’t Work the Way We Thought It Did
recommendations.excerpt: Studies find it’s the quick loss of recent implicit memory that is holding the brain back. Dyslexia is not just about reading, or even language.

recommendations.title: Pure Magic: The Oral History of Prince’s Super Bowl XLI Halftime Show
recommendations.excerpt: As the heavens opened up and rain poured down, the Purple One ran through a handful of covers and some of his own songs, delivering an iconic set on the biggest stage possible and only expanding his legend.

recommendations.title: English Is Not Normal
recommendations.excerpt: No, English isn’t uniquely vibrant or mighty or adaptable. But it really is weirder than pretty much every other language.

recommendations.title: Mommy Can’t Talk Right Now — She’s Dopamine Fasting
recommendations.excerpt: I tried the Silicon Valley trend and came up with a better idea.

recommendations.title: The Ghost Hunter
recommendations.excerpt: For hundreds of years, there were rumors of a shipwrecked treasure on the Oregon coast. But no one found anything, until Cameron La Follette began digging.

recommendations.title: The Twitch streamer behind Tfue’s custom $3,500 mechanical keyboard
recommendations.excerpt: When Tae Ha Kim began streaming himself constructing mechanical keyboards on Twitch roughly two years ago, he didn’t think it would be a viable replacement for his San Francisco programming career.

recommendations.title: Why you see online ads for stuff you buy in the real world
recommendations.excerpt: Stop me if you’ve heard this before: You go to a store, browse its wares, consider or even make a purchase, and then go home, only to find a bunch of ads from that very store — perhaps of the very item you bought — following you around the internet.

recommendations.title: Their Son’s Heart Saved His Life. So He Rode 1,426 Miles to Meet Them.
recommendations.excerpt: to get the letters right. To capture her boy who, just a few short months before, had been so full of life, energy, and love. To distill him into the two dimensionality of words on paper.

recommendations.title: How Did the World’s Smallest Flightless Bird Get to Inaccessible Island?
recommendations.excerpt: The first scientists to describe the animal thought it might have walked.

recommendations.title: The Outsize Influence of Your Middle-School Friends
recommendations.excerpt: Early in 2010, the year we moved to Hong Kong, our three boys were 11, eight, and six. When we sat them down to tell them we’d be moving there for a few years, we tried to sell it as a challenging adventure. Their responses were mixed. Jake was anxious. Alex, our baby, was excited.

recommendations.title: Trapped in Iran
recommendations.excerpt: In July 2019 Nicolas Pelham, The Economist’s Middle East correspondent, received a rare journalist’s visa to Iran. On the day he was due to fly home, he was detained.

recommendations.title: Unpacking the Power of Privileged Neighborhoods
recommendations.excerpt: A study shows that growing up in an affluent community brings “compounding privileges” and higher educational attainment—especially for white residents.

recommendations.title: The Mystery of Why Some People Become Sudden Geniuses
recommendations.excerpt: There’s mounting evidence that brain damage has the power to unlock extraordinary creative talents. What can this teach us about how geniuses are made?

recommendations.title: Time Management Is About More Than Life Hacks
recommendations.excerpt: Project creep, slipping deadlines, and a to-do list that seems to get longer each day — these experiences are all too common in both life and work.

recommendations.title: How We Pay Attention Changes the Very Shape of Our Brains
recommendations.excerpt: Imagine arriving at the airport just in time to catch a plane. Everything in your behavior betrays the heightened concentration of your attention.

recommendations.title: How to talk someone out of bigotry
recommendations.excerpt: These scientists keep proving that reducing prejudice is possible. It’s just not easy.
